qas.question: What other religion has history as being part of Presbyterian?
In what year did the parliament of Scotland adopt the Scots Confession?
Which book was touted for establishing regulations for church and government?
Christianity is part of the history of which religion?
During which 17th century reformation did the beginning of Presbyterianism occur?
Other than Geneva, which countries can the Presbyterian church be traced back to?
Which Englishman had a major influence in Presbyterianism?
In which year did the Parliament of England adopt the Scots Confession?

context: <b4_0>Presbyterian<b4_0/> history is part of the history of <a0_0>Christianity<a0_0/>, but the beginning of Presbyterianism as a distinct movement occurred during the 16th-century <b5_0>Protestant Reformation<b5_0/>. As the Catholic Church resisted the reformers, several different theological movements splintered from the Church and bore different denominations. Presbyterianism was especially influenced by the French theologian <a1_0><b7_0>John Calvin<b7_0/><a1_0/>, who is credited with the development of Reformed theology, and the work of John Knox, a Scotsman who studied with Calvin in Geneva, Switzerland and brought his teachings back to Scotland. The Presbyterian church traces its ancestry back primarily to <b6_0>England and Scotland<b6_0/>. In August <a2_0><b8_0>1560<b8_0/><a2_0/> the Parliament of Scotland adopted the Scots Confession as the creed of the Scottish Kingdom. In December 1560, the <a3_0>First Book of Discipline<a3_0/> was published, outlining important doctrinal issues but also establishing regulations for church government, including the creation of ten ecclesiastical districts with appointed superintendents which later became known as presbyteries.
